content.description: An excellent boulder problem on a blunt, overhung arete with salt&pepper white&black granite. A very aesthetic line.
content.location: Follow the approach trail to Frontiertown. After turning right, before coming to the cliff, there is an impossible-to-miss boulder on the right. On the far side of the boulder (closest to the cliff), ascending a blunt, overhung arete, is an excellent line capped by cross-hashed seams. The stand start goes at V5/6. The sit start is an open project likely in the V8/harder range.

content.description: Good jams the whole way up, good stances for placing gear, a fun finish. Start up a short layback on a left-facing corner to a ledge with a small tree below a V-shaped crack. Follow the crack to its end (below a roof), then exit climber's left to a slung cedar tree.
content.location: Approach as for Dark Side of the Loon. 50' to the climber's right, around the arete (walk between a huge cedar and the cliff), find a V shaped crack above a short left-facing corner. The face to the left has a couple triangular shaped holds. This face has been attempted on top rope, but most of the climbing was not fun and the face is very dirty.

content.description: 10 total quickdraws and an optional BD #0.4Climbs the impressive face (deceptively overhanging) at the height of the land where the approach trail meets the cliff.Start up the middle of the black face with orange moss on great holds. Manage the pump as you climb up the cracked face to the horizontal (optional 0.4 BD), then commit and pull hard through a devious crux (V5 boulder problem). Hold it together through easier but very enjoyable climbing on good holds to the chains, then enjoy the view. Clean falls, good clipping stances.Pretty much pumpy 5.10+/11- with a V5 crux.
content.protection: 10 quickdraws and an optional # 0.4 BD cam

content.description: West facing cliff with a short approachThe top of the cliff can be reached by hiking to the extreme climber's left (climber's right is more ledgy and 3rd-4th class).
